“One of big things I’ve come to believe in my couple of decades working on internet stuff is that great product design is always holistic: Always working in relation to a whole system of interconnected parts, never concerned only with atomic decisions. And this perspective just straight-up cannot emerge from a piecemeal, GitHub-issues approach to fixing problems. **This is the main reason it’s vanishingly rare to see good product design in open source**.”

Also considering adding Lists support so you can build and curate lists of accounts that are easily shareable.

Imma ship this before I get too carried away 😅 #fediverseInfo #peopleDirectory

title: The 19th Century Woman Who Predicted Global Warming

last_post.content:
An appreciation of Eunice Foote, the suffragist and scientist who — way back in 1856 — conducted the first known experiment to demonstrate that CO2 was a heat-trapping gas …

…. and who, when writing up a paper of her findings, theorized that if the Earth’s atmosphere accumulated lots of CO2, the planet would warm up also

Alas, her work was lost to history until quite recently: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-19th-century-woman-who-predicted-global-warming-af93f6b473ce

A “friend” link in case you’re not a Medium subscriber: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-19th-century-woman-who-predicted-global-warming-af93f6b473ce?sk=2132215cf9d7a17c2f7d1e43d0ffd7af

title: People Can't Believe This Photo of a Bird Isn't Photoshopped or AI-Generated

last_post.content:
New dress controversy. Is the water blue or gold?

Not photoshop. Not AI.

https://mymodernmet.com/kenichi-ohno-bird-photo-illusion/

"So what is happening behind the egret that is causing the illusion? In the upper right-hand corner, there is a cream-colored wall. What we see below the wall is its reflection in the water and the position of the photographer has allowed for a perfectly straight “cut” in the composition, so one side is all water and the other side is the wall and its reflection."

Photo by Kenichi Ohno

People are calling today the 30th birthday of the web; more accurately it’s the 30th birthday of CERN releasing the source code. I vividly remember websites being a curiosity among FTP servers, Usenet newsgroups, and gopher holes.

Here’s to this marvelous technology, Earth’s biggest Choose Your Own Adventure book, one of the most backwardly compatible systems ever built. Modern browsers may be elaborate interpreter-compilers but they still render the first site: http://info.cern.ch/hypertext/WWW/TheProject.html

a great point Kate Crawford made in her interview on Chris Hayes’ podcast is that AI is essentially an **extractive** industry that 1) “mines” content from the internet for its models, 2) depends on cheap labor in developing countries, and 3) uses a **huge** amount of natural resources in the sense that it takes a lot of computing power and therefore energy to train the models and poop out its amusing little answers. https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/amp/ncna1304427

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: Bluesky’s CEO on competing with Twitter and Mastodon

(For two years, Jay Graber gave no interviews to the public. Zero transparency. So much for Dorsey's "out in the open" promises.)

During that time, Dorsey privately (later, publicly) lobbied for Musk, "the singular solution I trust" to take over Twitter.

Dorsey helped fund Musk's takeover to the tune of $1 billion, making him one of Musk's top backers (after Qatar).

"Musk reportedly ended the company’s ties with #Bluesky [sometime after] he took over Twitter."

title: Research Paper | Developer Thriving: The four factors that drive Software Developer Productivity across Industries

last_post.content:
@grimalkina et al. refer to "bottom-up" visibility: "communicating engineering effort to organizations". Frequent commits, open PRs, etc. create transparency, but this data must be "translated" to the rest of the organization. https://www.pluralsight.com/resource-center/guides/developer-thriving-research-paper

The New Yorker piece talks about not mistaking transparency as a first-order good: really, what I care about is *trust*. On cross-functional teams, transparency needs to be joined with translation to achieve trust. Transparency alone is not enough.

Klar, heute ist Tag der Arbeit, aber am nächsten Montag ist Tag der *Doktorarbeit*, denn dann läuft die Bewerbungsfrist für die Doktorand*innen-Stellen in meiner Arbeitsgruppe ab! Du willst in den nächsten vier Jahren in der Hauptstadt der Herzen (und der tatsächlichen Hauptstadt) leben und dich mit Korpuslinguistik und/oder kognitiver Linguistik beschäftigen? Good day Mastodon! Here is my third and last (hopefully friendly) reminder about my online survey.

I am writing to kindly remind you about the online survey I launched a few weeks ago as part of my #PhD in #digitalhumanities, aiming to understand the main practices and activities of the individuals involved in the International Image Interoperability Framework (#IIIF) and/or the #LinkedArt communities.

If you haven't had a chance to fill in the survey yet, I would greatly appreciate your help in taking 10 to 20 minutes of your time to share your insights with me. Your participation would be invaluable to my research.

https://forms.gle/Djvuf7HrrFqxXFxd8 (closing on Sunday, 7 May)

Many thanks! :)

@IIIF@glammr.us @iiif@a.gup.pe #culturalheritage #sts @digitalhumanities

title: NASA’s Webb Scores Another Ringed World With New Image of Uranus

last_post.content:
This zoomed-in image of #Uranus, captured by #JWST’s Near-Infrared Camera (NIRCam) Feb. 6, 2023, reveals stunning views of the #planet’s rings.

The planet displays a blue hue in this representative-color image, made by combining data from two filters at 1.4 and 3.0 microns, which are shown here as blue and orange, respectively.

#astronomy #astrophotography

title: Opinion | How Finland managed to virtually end homelessness

last_post.content: "Determined to pack more homeless people into Toronto’s overcrowded shelters, officials have come up with a solution: reduce the number of inches between beds. There’s a certain logic to this and it may be the best we can do — given our refusal to consider solutions that would actually be innovative." https://www.thestar.com/opinion/contributors/2023/04/20/how-finland-managed-to-virtually-end-homelessness.html "Instead of abandoning the homeless, they housed them. And that led to an insight: people tend to function better when they’re not living on the street or under a bridge. "

This article on the interplay between English and German in Berlin, including the oft-maligned Denglisch, original German Anglicisms like “Handy”, English words whose meaning has slipped like “actual” for “current”, and the question of how to adapt English loanwords to German grammar (i.e.,“gedownloadet” vs. “downgeloadet”), is comprehensive and worth a read: https://europeanreviewofbooks.com/beamer-dressman-bodybag/en

Tangentially, I have found that some of the observations also apply to English as used in Sweden.

At the onset of the pandemic, Dr. Murthy joined the entire Biden campaign staff to talk to us about loneliness and exhaustion. He advised us how to be present, even when we weren't physically present, and to focus on better, not more. His piece here rings powerfully back to that conversation.

/kbin is a Reddit alternative for the Fediverse!

That's right, it's ActivityPub-enabled.

Which means that it connects with Mastodon, Pixelfed, Calckey, Friendica -- 100+ platforms that use ActivityPub.

What are its features?

* upvotes and downvotes
* comments
* feeds for "Top", "Hot", and "Newest"

I think it's more functional and better looking than Reddit.

This might be more than a Reddit alternative. It could be a Reddit killer!

https://kbin.social

@fediversenews

title: Heat wave map: See where Americans face the most extreme heat risk

last_post.content:
This map gives "red states" a whole new meaning.

If you live in the US, you can type in your zip code and see an estimate of how many days per year will have a heat index of over 100 °F in 2053:

https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/interactive/2022/extreme-heat-risk-map-us/

The model used is explained here:

https://riskfactor.com/methodology/heat

The heat index, developed by the National Weather Service, takes humidity into account:

https://www.weather.gov/ama/heatindex

title: Getting What You Measure: Four common pitfalls in using software metrics for project management: Queue: Vol 10, No 5

last_post.content:
I also quite like how the Pluralsight developer productivity study built on our "Getting What You Measure" paper, rephrasing our common metric pitfalls as:

1. We tend to measure things without enough context.
2. We're concerned about the appearance, but not really the meaning of what we've measured.
3. We have not measured enough things.
4. We measure many things, but they do not feel related to each other.

https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/2208917.2229115

https://www.pluralsight.com/resource-center/guides/developer-thriving-research-paper

#DeveloperProductivity #Pluralsight

ActivityPub can support portable identities, using the infrastructure and protocol that we already have: https://shadowfacts.net/2023/activitypub-portable-identity/

The crux of the issue with current software like Mastodon is that people and posts are identified by where they’re hosted, not who they belong to. It’s as if the URL for my blog post was https://5.161.136.163/2023/activitypub-portable-identity/. It moves the post from being controlled by me, the owner of shadowfacts.net, to my hosting provider who controls that IP address. But the web doesn’t work like that, and nor does ActivityPub have to.
